values: Here's your first peek at our new book- Rock Testament, a beautiful collaboration of Eugene's powerful art and Kimberley's writing. Order one now at http://www.etsy.com/listing/73191196/rock-testament-smart-philosophical-tale and get a free postcard and 1" pin with every book. But hurry - supplies are limited!

Very soon we'll launhing The Rock Testament Book. Here are some tips we've got from the global adviser: Well, first and foremost, press coverage is pretty vital. The local media – especially radio – attract bigger fish like sharks around chum, but they might only attend if there’s a story within a story and nothing attracts a story as much as celebrity. If you know one, get him or her there … even if you have to pay them. A big name controversial author would be good, but a band member or an actor or just known and attractive public figure, is all the better. Who could be that smashing character? We have no budget but plenty of ideas in mind. And we also nice pupil :) More about the book here: http://www.facebook.com/Editions.Tchai

We are working hard on our new book you know. Today we show you the most sacredness corner at Tchai, our Secret Garden - Serge Razbojnikoff's - our designer - workplace. Hey! We also have Facebook domain! http://www.facebook.com/Editions.Tchai Visit us there!

I considered LJ dead. Until I had to kill my FB account and erase my FB profile.
There is no free cheese.

OK, I have to admit it with deepest sorrow and regret - and I am 100% serious and sincere about this - I am no longer present in my virtual body on LJ... I still believe in LJ - it is unique and it does not need to compete with "social networks"... LJ is a true diary, just like an old fashioned diary - it allows extra long thoughtful entries and its content is rich and deep.

It's me, not you, as they say. I became so engrossed with my business... I still love writing and philosophy; I do read and sometimes pretty insightful and original thoughts cross my mind. But I no longer have the urge and the time and the mood for those good old-fashioned posts... For sure, I miss that LJ existence. But now I turn more often to a real, paper and ink diary, which is good.

Anyway, friends, I am not dead, I am alive and well and you can find me on FB, oh yes, on FB...  Lilies of the Valley | Facebook
I love you all, thank you for LJ brotherhood of thinking individuals I was so proud to be a member of for 4 years.
I love you! LJ is never a ghost town for me.

Hindu Lullaby - Russian animation project.
The song, the melody, the voice just mesmerize me. When the violins kick in I feel that in my previous life I must have been Indian. I feel the same, though, when I listen to Middle Eastern melodies.

So soft, so comfortable, so cozy. Today we took a walk through the Willow Lane, feeling we were in the fairy tale, enchanted forest. Spring is coming, but as they say: "En avril, n'ôte pas un fil; en mai, fait ce qu'il te plait" - In April, don't take off a thread, in May, dress up as you wish. This jacket was just right for this treacherous spring weather. We both stayed warm and cozy and Theo fell asleep, her cheek on the feather-soft shawl collar of my jacket. I covered her from the wind with the jacket's warm, but breathable tail.

And it's here



One Of a Kind Applique Night Bird BabyWearing Wraparound Jacket Fairy Tale Looks Great With the Baby or Solo

For those who didn't grow up during that era this video might seem anything from tacky to odd.

And it well might be - with a lip-syncing talking head  on B&W screen TV, dated melody and uncomfortable looking school uniform...
When I look at this video I remember those white aprons - we were told in advance to write down in our school journals that on such and such day we should come in "holiday" attire - that is to wear white starched pinafore instead of every day black one. I loved all that - white bows in our pig tails, white cuffs and collars we had to keep clean and replace often. There was a hidden competition between girls - who gets the most fancy white cuffs and aprons. School dress code was very strict, but one could go very free-thinking in cuffs and collars - add lace, use any white fabric one wants :)

Then, when I look at that place in her dance when she turns her head, making her pony tail sway - I really feel that sensation of having your healthy thick mop of hair pulled back in a tight pony tail and yes, I would do the same - make my pony tail sway like that. It's the feeling of being strong, young, healthy.

The movie is about a pre-teen girl who is regarded as a "problem child" in her school - oh, nothing like problem kid nowadays - she was just too much in her dreams, all innocent rebellion against boredom. Her mom is a geologist and spends lots of time away on field trips - so she lives with her older sis - the one who scolds her at the end of the clip for "decorating" the kitchen with stickers. Those are not stickeers, BTW - there were called "transfer pictures" and they were very very hard to take off.

The song is about "The Forest Deer" who will come and carry her away to a wonderful land.

In 1989 we came to America and settled in Bensohurst. I lived there for 5 years before leaving for France. Returned many times and my family is still living there, in the same place.
When I heard this song for the first time I was so surprised - after all, who ever heard of Bensonhurst/ It's not Little Italy or even Brighton Beach.
Bensonhurst changed a lot since 1989. It's no longer an Italian neighbourhood. Oh, Getty's personal driver lived in the hous next door from ours - and on the front step of his house he was shot. Th edetectives were on every corner, questionning everybody.
Now Bensonhurst became more of a Russian-Korean-Chinese place - always a great place to visit or to live. And one can walk to the Ocean and look and look at the Verrazano bridge...

The Toronto "My City" group show is back for a second year. urbanscape gallery is hosting a group exhibition focused on exploring city themes and urban phenomena: the experience of urban living, the people, the buildings, the spaces, the relationships, and whatever else.

The show will feature the work of our own USk Toronto correspondent Eugene Zhilinsky and a number of other artists, including: Reza Aliabadi, Iliya Blanusa, Kat Citroen, Jacquie Cobb, Eleanor Doran, Ray Ferris, Janos Gardonyi, Florin Hategan, Jonah Humphrey, Eva Lewarne, Michael Mahovlich, Olga Nabatova, Jackieramo, Kiely Ramos, Amy Roger, Katya Trischuk, James William and Kara Williams.

Opening night reception is Wednesday, September 9. The show takes place during the Junction Arts Festival, which goes from September 3 to 19.

http://www.urbansketchers.com/

"The kingdom of Danhomè is well known for its appliquéd cloth. Created at the court, it was especially devoted to the celebration of the Fon monarchs' assumed name and outstanding deeds, particularly during the 18th and 19th centuries. They attained a sufficiently high degree of art for them to be often given to other nations with which the kingdom had connections. They served as marks of friendship. Since the conquest of the kingdom by the French in 1894, appliquéd cloth has portrayed a wider variety of subjects relating to daily life. They are also a source of inspiration for contemporary creators." from: http://www.epa-prema.net/abomeyGB/resources/hangings.htm)

An article by a prominent New York art critic Raz Johansen:

On “The Moccasins” by Tania Yuditskaya

At first look, each image from the series “The Moccasins” by Tania Yuditskaya seems like a rendering of two moccasins placed side by side. Floating in a non-space, each
detail of their form minutely depicted, they look like an Objekt Plakat advertisement (with the signature as brand) from the 1920’s. But this artful hero shot is much more than just that. “The Moccasins” are portrayals of absent characters, excluded by the picture plane.

The first character is the Native American, also perhaps the person that crafted these moccasins in the first place. The original creator is not only absent from these images, but also from any part of the American landscape we see on any given day. “The Moccasins” are a poignant reminder of this.
The second character is the artist herself, her hand conveys the massage of the moccasins to the viewer, and her massage is responsible for the floating object, and the controlled, inscrutable rendering of the subject.

The third character is the art lover, the possessor of the gaze, also perhaps the consumer, who can posses these moccasins in more ways than one, who can posses the land these moccasins walk on while their bearer cannot.

This brings us back to the absent characters, is the wearer of the moccasins the Native American that has granted them to this immediate audience as a cultural artifact to be
purchased and assimilated or the artist herself? Is the artist’s presentation a prospect to the American consumer linked to the merchandising of Native American heritage to consumer culture? Or perchance the moccasins are a medium for the artist to portray the current economy of social circumstance fully?

“The Moccasins” put the viewer in the shoes of a potential owner and they surely give him/her the gaze. They also ask the viewer to walk in them or remain on the side of the picture plane that we presently occupy, contemplating them, or debating to buy.
.
 find 11 more mystical paintings of Native American Moccasins here, on my Etsy
